item.title: About me
item.description: Interests I mainly work on inference and analysis of microbial networks. My focus lies on emergent properties, such as hub species, modules and motifs. In addition to accurate detection of such properties, I want to better study microbial dynamics to learn how these properties arise. Outside the lab, I enjoy gardening. My proudest gardening accomplishment is my seed-grown Musa velutina, or pink banana. Education PhD in Microbial Networks 2017 KU Leuven MSc in Biology - Molecular Development and Gene Regulation - Cum Laude 2015-2017 Wageningen UR BSc in Molecular Biology - Cum Laude 2012-2015 Wageningen UR Biography In 2017, I became a doctoral student at the lab of Karoline Faust.

item.title: Conferences & Talks
item.description: 3 May 2019, RSG Belgium Student Symposium A clustering algorithm for weighted ecological networks 24 April 2019, IAFP European Symposium Introduction to microbial networks 13 March 2019, workshop on microbiome research @ Utrecht University Interactive tutorial on microbial association networks 25 January 2019, Microbiota Data Analysis Workshop Lecture & tutorial on analysis of microbial networks 13 August 2018, ISME 2017 Poster presentation 3 May 2018, Solvay Workshop Poster presentation 14 February 2018, Netherlands Annual Ecology Meeting Talk on data from upcoming work: From hairballs to hypotheses

item.title: Teaching
item.description: You can find my teaching materials here. All material is available under the Apache-2.0 license; you are free to reuse and modify any content available. For my participation in workshops, please check the ‘Conferences & Talks’section.
